a.g: By those [winds] scattering [dust] dispersing
And those [clouds] carrying a load [of water]
And those [ships] sailing with ease
And those [angels] apportioning [each] matter,
Indeed, what you are promised is true.
And indeed, the recompense is to occur.
By the heaven containing pathways,
Indeed, you are in differing speech.
Deluded away from the Qur'an is he who is deluded.
Destroyed are the falsifiers
Who are within a flood [of confusion] and heedless.
They ask, "When is the Day of Recompense?"
[It is] the Day they will be tormented over the Fire
[And will be told], "Taste your torment. This is that for which you were impatient."
Indeed, the righteous will be among gardens and springs,
Accepting what their Lord has given them. Indeed, they were before that doers of good.
They used to sleep but little of the night,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, the world [al-dunya] and its permissible pleasures, natural dispositions incline towards them with a natural inclination, so the heart [al-qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking them, while acts of worship require exertion, and the sincerity [ikhlas] of the heart within them is only achieved at some times. So whoever desires Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse all his times in obedience [ta'a]. And whoever desires to tip the scale of good deeds, let him occupy most of his times with them. For if one mixes a righteous deed with an evil one, his affair is perilous, yet hope is not severed, and pardon from the generosity of Allah is awaited. And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "They used to sleep but little of the night, and in the hours before dawn they would ask forgiveness." This indicates that the successful ones are those whose sleep at night is little and who seek forgiveness [istighfar] in the hours before dawn, thus combining little slumber with abundant seeking of forgiveness, so that this may be a path to watching over the times and filling them with remembrance [dhikr] and obedience [ta'a] in a manner of constancy, so they may attain the sought-after virtue of reward [thawab] and forgiveness [maghfirah].

a.g: And in the hours before dawn they would ask forgiveness,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, the Most High says: "And in the hours before dawn, they would seek forgiveness [yastaghfirūn]." And He, may He be glorified and exalted, said: "Allah, the Most High, descends every night to the lowest heaven [samā' al-dunyā] when the last third of the night remains, and the Almighty says: 'Who calls upon Me that I may answer him? Who asks of Me that I may give to him? Who seeks My forgiveness [yastaghfirnī] that I may forgive him?'" And it is said that Ya'qub, peace be upon him, only said, "I will seek forgiveness for you from my Lord," so that he might supplicate at the time of the pre-dawn [al-saḥar]. So it is said that he stood at the time of the pre-dawn [waqt al-saḥar] supplicating, and his sons were saying 'Amen' behind him, and Allah, the Almighty, revealed: "I have forgiven them and made them prophets."
Vol1 book 9

a.g: And from their properties was [given] the right of the [needy] petitioner and the deprived.
And on the earth are signs for the certain [in faith]
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k07
Indeed, to it [the heart] did God, glorified and exalted is He, call by His saying: "We will show them Our signs [ayat] in the horizons and within themselves." And by His saying, exalted is He: "And on the earth are signs [ayat] for those of certainty [muqinin], and within yourselves. Will you not then see?"

a.g: And in yourselves. Then will you not see?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, the Qur'an has come urging reflection upon these signs [ayat], as Allah the Exalted has said: "Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs [ayat] for those of understanding [uli al-albab]." And as He the Exalted has said: "And among His signs [ayat]..." from the beginning of the Qur'an to its end. So let us mention the manner of reflection upon some of the signs [ayat]. So among His signs [ayat] is the human [insan], created from a sperm-drop [nutfah]. And the closest thing to you is your own self [nafs], and within you are wonders indicating the majesty of Allah the Exalted, which lifetimes would not suffice to stand upon a tenth of a tenth of them, while you are heedless [ghafil] of them. So O you who is heedless [ghafil] of your own self [nafs] and ignorant of it, how do you aspire to the knowledge [ma'rifah] of other than you? And Allah the Exalted has commanded you to contemplate [tadabbur] within your own self [nafs] in His Mighty Book, saying: "And in yourselves [anfusikum]—then will you not see?" And He mentioned that you are created from a foul sperm-drop [nutfah], saying: "Destroyed is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfah] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the path easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in his grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." And He the Exalted said: "And among His signs [ayat] is that He created you from dust; then, suddenly you were human beings dispersing." And He the Exalted said: "Was he not a sperm-drop [nutfah] from semen emitted? Then he was a clinging clot ['alaqah]; and He created and proportioned." And He the Exalted said: "Did We not create you from a despised water [ma'in]? Then We placed it in a firm lodging [qararin makin], for a known extent." And He said: "Does man [insan] not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfah]? Then at once he is a clear adversary." And He said: "Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfah] mixed [amshaj];" then He mentioned how He made the sperm-drop [nutfah] a clinging clot ['alaqah], and the clinging clot ['alaqah] a chewed lump [mudghah], and the chewed lump [mudghah] bones. He the Exalted said: "And certainly did We create man [insan] from an extract of clay. Then We placed him as a sperm-drop [nutfah] in a firm lodging [qararin makin]. Then We made the sperm-drop [nutfah] into a clinging clot ['alaqah]..." So the repeated mention of the sperm-drop [nutfah] in the Mighty Book is not for its word to be heard while reflection upon its meaning is abandoned. So look now at the sperm-drop [nutfah]: it is a droplet of foul water; if left for an hour for the air to strike it, it would spoil and become putrid. How did the Lord of lords bring it forth from the loins and the ribs? And how did He bring together the male and the female and cast affection [ulfah] and love [mahabbah] into their hearts [qulub]? And how did He lead them by the chain of love [mahabbah] and desire [shahwah] to union? And how did He extract the sperm-drop [nutfah] from the man by the movement of intercourse? And how did He draw the blood of menstruation from the depths of the veins and gather it in the womb? Then how did He create the newborn from the sperm-drop [nutfah] and nourish it with the water of menstruation and feed it until it grew, increased, and became large? And how did He make the sperm-drop [nutfah], which is white and shining, into a red clinging clot ['alaqah]? Then how did He make it a chewed lump [mudghah]? Then how did He divide the parts of the sperm-drop [nutfah], which are equal and similar, into bones, nerves, veins, tendons, and flesh? Then how did He compose from the flesh, nerves, and veins the apparent limbs: the roundness of the head, the aperture of hearing, sight, the nose, the mouth, and all the openings? Then He extended the hand and the leg and divided their ends into fingers, and divided the fingers into fingertips? Then how did He compose the internal organs: the heart [qalb], the stomach, the liver, the spleen, the lung, the womb, the bladder, and the intestines—each one with a specific form, a specific measure, for a specific function? Then how did He divide each of these organs into other divisions, composing the eye from seven layers, each layer with a specific attribute and a specific constitution?

a.g: And in the heaven is your provision and whatever you are promised.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, and what Allah has sworn by—so what is your estimation of that by which Allah, the Exalted, has sworn, and upon which He has made the provision [arzaq] dependent and attributed it to Himself? For He, the Exalted, has said: "And in the heaven is your provision [rizq] and what you are promised."
Vol4 book2
Indeed, and what Allah has sworn by—so what is your estimation of that by which Allah, the Exalted, has sworn, and upon which He has made the provision [arzaq] dependent and attributed it to Himself? For He, the Exalted, has said: "And in the heaven is your provision [rizq] and what you are promised."
Vol4 book4

Then he recited: "And in the heaven is your provision [rizq] and what you are promised. And by the Lord of the heaven and the earth, indeed, it is truth—just as [you are] speaking."

a.g: Then by the Lord of the heaven and earth, indeed, it is truth - just as [sure as] it is that you are speaking.
Has there reached you the story of the honored guests of Abraham? -
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k01
Indeed, one of the two meanings in His, the Exalted's, saying, "Has there come to you the story of the honored guests [ḏayf] of Abraham?" is that they were honored [ukrimū] by the hastening of food to them. This is indicated by His, the Exalted's, saying, "Then he hastened to his household and brought a fat [samīn] calf [ʿijl]," and His saying, "Then he turned to his household and came with a fat [samīn] calf [ʿijl]." And "turning" [al-rawghān] is going with speed, and it is said: in concealment. And it is said: He came with a thigh of meat. And it is only called a calf [ʿijl] because he hastened it [ʿajjalahu] and did not tarry.

a.g: When they entered upon him and said, "[We greet you with] peace." He answered, "[And upon you] peace, [you are] a people unknown.
Then he went to his family and came with a fat [roasted] calf
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k01
Indeed, one of the meanings in His, the Exalted's, saying, "Has there reached you the story of the honored guests [ḏayf] of Abraham?" is that they were honored [ukrimū] by the hastening of food to them. This is indicated by His, the Exalted's, saying, "Then he hastened to his household and brought a fat calf [ʿijl]" and His saying, "Then he turned to his household and came with a fat calf [ʿijl samīn]." And "turning" [al-rawghān] is to go with speed, and it is said: in secrecy. And it is said: He came with a thigh of meat. And it is only called a calf [ʿijl] because he hastened it [ʿajjalahu] and did not tarry.

a.g: And placed it near them; he said, "Will you not eat?"
And he felt from them apprehension. They said, "Fear not," and gave him good tidings of a learned boy.
And his wife approached with a cry [of alarm] and struck her face and said, "[I am] a barren old woman!"
They said, "Thus has said your Lord; indeed, He is the Wise, the Knowing."
[Abraham] said, "Then what is your business [here], O messengers?"
They said, "Indeed, we have been sent to a people of criminals
To send down upon them stones of clay,
Marked in the presence of your Lord for the transgressors."
So We brought out whoever was in the cities of the believers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 2
Indeed, as for the correspondence [al-tarāduf], it is in His, the Exalted's, saying: "So We brought out whoever was in it of the believers. And We found not within it except a single house of the Muslims [muslimīn]." And it was, by consensus, only one house.

a.g: And We found not within them other than a [single] house of Muslims.
And We left therein a sign for those who fear the painful punishment.
And in Moses [was a sign], when We sent him to Pharaoh with clear authority.
But he turned away with his supporters and said," A magician or a madman."
So We took him and his soldiers and cast them into the sea, and he was blameworthy.
And in 'Aad [was a sign], when We sent against them the barren wind.
It left nothing of what it came upon but that it made it like disintegrated ruins.
And in Thamud, when it was said to them, "Enjoy yourselves for a time."
But they were insolent toward the command of their Lord, so the thunderbolt seized them while they were looking on.
And they were unable to arise, nor could they defend themselves.
And [We destroyed] the people of Noah before; indeed, they were a people defiantly disobedient.
And the heaven We constructed with strength, and indeed, We are [its] expander.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k09
Indeed, We built the sky [al-sama'] with strength [bi-aydin], and indeed, We are its expanders [lamusi'un].

a.g: And the earth We have spread out, and excellent is the preparer.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k09
Indeed, We built the sky [al-sama'] with strength, and indeed We are the Expanders [al-musi'un]. And the earth [al-ard] We spread out; so excellent are the Preparers [al-mahidun].

a.g: And of all things We created two mates; perhaps you will remember.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, the different meanings require different names. The angel [malak] is an expression for a creation whom God—Exalted is His Majesty—created for the outpouring of good [khayr], the bestowal of knowledge ['ilm], the unveiling of truth [haqq], the promise of good, and the command to righteousness. He created it and subjugated it for that. And the devil [shaytan] is an expression for a creation whose function is the opposite of that: it is the promise of evil [sharr], the command to indecency, and the instilling of fear of poverty when one intends good. Thus, the whispering [waswasa] is in opposition to the inspiration [ilham], and the devil [shaytan] is in opposition to the angel [malak], and divine facilitation [tawfiq] is in opposition to abandonment [khidhlan]. And the allusion to this is in His—Exalted is He—saying: "And of all things We have created pairs." For all existent things are opposites, paired, except God—Exalted is He—for He is the Singular [fard] who has no opposite. Rather, He is the One True [al-Wahid al-Haqq], the Creator of all pairs.

a.g: So flee to Allah. Indeed, I am to you from Him a clear warner.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k09
So flee to Allah [fa-firru ila Allah]. Indeed, I am to you from Him a clear warner [nathir mubin]. He said: So a people fled. Were it not for what Allah, majestic is His praise, placed within prophethood [nubuwwah] of the secret [sirr], we would have said they are not superior to these, in what has reached us that the angels, peace be upon them, would meet them and shake their hands, and the clouds and the wild beasts would pass by one of them and he would call to them and they would answer him, and he would ask them, "Where have you been commanded?" and they would inform him—and he is not a prophet [nabi].

a.g: And do not make [as equal] with Allah another deity. Indeed, I am to you from Him a clear warner.
Similarly, there came not to those before them any messenger except that they said, "A magician or a madman."
Did they suggest it to them? Rather, they [themselves] are a transgressing people.
So leave them, [O Muhammad], for you are not to be blamed.
And remind, for indeed, the reminder benefits the believers.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j4 k08
And He, the Exalted, said: "And remind, for indeed the reminder benefits the believers." [51:55] This, and what follows its course, is the first station of vigilance [murabatah] with the self [nafs], and it is self-reckoning [muhasabah] before the action. And self-reckoning [muhasabah] is sometimes after the action and sometimes before it, as a warning. Allah, the Exalted, said: "And know that Allah knows what is within yourselves, so beware of Him." And this is for the future. And every consideration of the quantity and measure to know increase and decrease, then it is called self-reckoning [muhasabah]. So the consideration of what lies before the servant during his day to know his increase from his decrease is from self-reckoning [muhasabah]. And Allah, the Exalted, has said: "O you who have believed, when you go forth in the cause of Allah, investigate." And He, the Exalted, said: "O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate." And He, the Exalted, said: "And We have certainly created man and We know what his soul [nafs] whispers to him." He mentioned that as a warning and an alert to guard against it in the future. And 'Ubadah ibn al-Samit reported that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to a man who asked him to advise and exhort him: "If you intend a matter, then consider its consequence [‘aqibah]. If it is right guidance [rushd], then proceed with it, and if it is misguidance [ghayy], then desist from it." (The hadith of 'Ubadah ibn al-Samit: "If you intend a matter, then consider its consequence [‘aqibah]" has preceded.) And some of the wise said: "If you want the intellect [‘aql] to prevail over the desire [hawa], then do not act upon the decree of the appetite [shahwah] until you look at the consequence [‘aqibah], for the abiding of regret [nadamah] in the heart [qalb] is longer than the abiding of the lightness of appetite [shahwah]." And Luqman said: "Indeed, the believer, when he perceives the consequence [‘aqibah], is safe from regret [nadamah]." And Shaddad ibn Aws reported from him, peace be upon him, that he said: "The intelligent one [kayyis] is he who holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana] and works for what is after death [mawt]. And the fool [ahmaq] is he who follows his soul [nafs] its desire [hawa] and makes wishes upon Allah." (The hadith "The intelligent one [kayyis] is he who holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana] and works for what is after death [mawt]" has preceded.) "Holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana]" means he reckons it. And the Day of Recompense [yawm al-din] is the Day of Account [hisab]. And His saying, "Are we indeed to be judged [madinun]?" means "Are we indeed to be brought to account [muhasabun]?" And 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Reckon with yourselves [hasibu anfusakum] before you are reckoned with, and weigh them before they are weighed, and prepare for the greatest presentation." And he wrote to Abu Musa al-Ash'ari: "Reckon your soul [nafs] in times of ease before the reckoning of hardship." And he said to Ka'b: "How do you find it in the Book of Allah?" He said: "Woe to the judges [dayyan] of the earth from the Judge [dayyan] of the heavens," so he struck him with the whip. And he said: "Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs]." So Ka'b said: "O Commander of the Faithful, it is next to it in the Torah; there is not a letter between them: 'Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs].'" And all of this is an indication to self-reckoning [muhasabah] for the future, when He said: "Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs]."
j4 k08

If it is right guidance [rushd], then proceed with it, and if it is misguidance [ghayy], then desist from it." (The hadith of 'Ubadah ibn al-Samit: "If you intend a matter, then consider its consequence [‘aqibah]" has preceded.) And some of the wise said: "If you want the intellect [‘aql] to prevail over the desire [hawa], then do not act upon the decree of the appetite [shahwah] until you look at the consequence [‘aqibah], for the abiding of regret [nadamah] in the heart [qalb] is longer than the abiding of the lightness of appetite [shahwah]." And Luqman said: "Indeed, the believer, when he perceives the consequence [‘aqibah], is safe from regret [nadamah]." And Shaddad ibn Aws reported from him, peace be upon him, that he said: "The intelligent one [kayyis] is he who holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana] and works for what is after death [mawt]. And the fool [ahmaq] is he who follows his soul [nafs] its desire [hawa] and makes wishes upon Allah." (The hadith "The intelligent one [kayyis] is he who holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana] and works for what is after death [mawt]" has preceded.) "Holds his soul [nafs] to account [dana]" means he reckons it. And the Day of Recompense [yawm al-din] is the Day of Account [hisab]. And His saying, "Are we indeed to be judged [madinun]?" means "Are we indeed to be brought to account [muhasabun]?" And 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Reckon with yourselves [hasibu anfusakum] before you are reckoned with, and weigh them before they are weighed, and prepare for the greatest presentation." And he wrote to Abu Musa al-Ash'ari: "Reckon your soul [nafs] in times of ease before the reckoning of hardship." And he said to Ka'b: "How do you find it in the Book of Allah?" He said: "Woe to the judges [dayyan] of the earth from the Judge [dayyan] of the heavens," so he struck him with the whip. And he said: "Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs]." So Ka'b said: "O Commander of the Faithful, it is next to it in the Torah; there is not a letter between them: 'Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs].'" And all of this is an indication to self-reckoning [muhasabah] for the future, when He said: "Except for he who reckons his soul [nafs]."

a.g: And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 5
Indeed, to this He alluded, may He be exalted, in His saying: "And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me [li-ya'budun]." Thus, everything between the heaven and the earth is a created thing [hadith] occurring according to a necessary order [tartib wajib] and a binding truth [haqq lazim]; it is inconceivable for it to be other than as it has occurred, and according to this order [tartib] in which it is found. And nothing is delayed except in anticipation of its condition [shart], for the conditioned [mashrut] before its condition [shart] is impossible [muhal], and the impossible [muhal] cannot be described as being within power [maqdur]. Thus, knowledge ['ilm] is not delayed after the sperm-drop [nutfah] except due to the absence of the condition [shart] of life [hayat], nor is will [iradah] delayed after knowledge ['ilm] except due to the absence of the condition [shart] of knowledge ['ilm]. And all of that is the method [minhaj] of the Necessary [al-Wajib] and the order [tartib] of the Truth [al-Haqq]. There is in none of that play [la'ib] or chance [ittifaq]; rather, all of that is with wisdom [hikmah] and management [tadbir]. And comprehending [tafhim] that is difficult ['asir].

Vol4 book2
Indeed, then, whoever employs a thing in a direction other than the direction for which it was created, and not in the manner intended for it, has indeed disbelieved in the blessing [ni'mah] of Allah, the Most High. So, whoever strikes another with his hand has disbelieved in the blessing of the hand, for the hand was created for him to repel with it from himself what would destroy him and to take what benefits him, not to destroy another with it. And whoever looks at the face of one who is not forbidden has disbelieved in the blessing of the eye and the blessing of the sun, for sight is perfected by them, and they were only created so that one may see with them what benefits him in his religion [din] and his worldly life [dunya], and to guard with them against what harms him in both. Thus, he has employed them in other than what was intended for them. And this is because the intended purpose from the creation of creation and the creation of the world [dunya] and its means is that creation may be aided by them to reach Allah, the Most High. And there is no reaching Him except through love [mahabbah] for Him and intimacy [uns] with Him in the world [dunya], and turning away from the deception of the world [dunya]. And there is no intimacy [uns] except through perpetual remembrance [dhikr], and no love [mahabbah] except through the knowledge [ma'rifah] attained through perpetual reflection [fikr]. And one cannot persist in remembrance [dhikr] and reflection [fikr] except through the persistence of the body [badan]. And the body [badan] does not remain except through nourishment [ghidha'], and nourishment [ghidha'] is not perfected except through the earth, water, and air. And that is not perfected except through the creation of the heaven and the earth, and the creation of all the limbs, outwardly and inwardly. So all of that is for the sake of the body [badan], and the body [badan] is the mount of the soul [nafs]. And what returns to Allah, the Most High, is the soul at peace [al-nafs al-mutma'innah] through prolonged worship ['ibadah] and knowledge [ma'rifah]. Therefore, He, the Most High, said: **"And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me. I do not want from them any provision..."** (51:56-57). So, whoever employs a thing in other than obedience to Allah has disbelieved in the blessing [ni'mah] of Allah in all the means [asbab] which are necessary for his embarking upon that disobedience [ma'siyah].

a.g: I do not want from them any provision, nor do I want them to feed Me.
Indeed, it is Allah who is the [continual] Provider, the firm possessor of strength.
And indeed, for those who have wronged is a portion [of punishment] like the portion of their predecessors, so let them not impatiently urge Me.
And woe to those who have disbelieved from their Day which they are promised.
